title: "Great leader" Steven Gerrard backed for managerial success by former Liverpool team-mate Luis Garcia
text:

Steven Gerrard can go on to become a great manager for Liverpool after serving his coaching apprenticeship in the club’s academy, according to former team-mate Luis Garcia. 
Kop idol Gerrard will step out at Anfield again on Saturday afternoon for a Liverpool Legends team against Real Madrid Legends, having left the Reds for LA Galaxy almost two years ago. 
After hanging up his boots last November, the former Liverpool captain returned as a coach at their youth academy, where his own playing career began. "He was the real inspiration for us. He made us believe" says Garcia of Gerrard in Istanbul (Photo: null) 
And because he made the journey from young hopeful to club legend, he is ideally placed to reach the same heights as a manager. 
“Stevie was a great leader as a player, on and off the pitch, and he can take that into coaching and management,” said Garcia, who was unveiled as the latest recruit for Star Sixes, a new six-a-side tournament for former internationals being held this summer — where he will face Gerrard. Team-mates a decade ago, Gerrard and Garcia will be rivals in this summer's Star Sixes (Photo: Daily Mirror) 
Garcia was famous for scoring what Jose Mourinho called the ‘ghost goal’ that took Liverpool past Chelsea into the 2005 Champions League final, and was in the team that Gerrard inspired to come back from 3-0 down against AC Milan to win the ‘Miracle in Istanbul’. 
“His goal gave us the belief that we could go on and win it, and he was the real inspiration for us. He made us believe,” said Garcia. 
Now, the Spaniard believes Gerrard has made the right move to start his coaching career with the next generation. Gerrard and Garcia join in celebrations of Liverpool's third goal in THAT 2005 final (Photo: Reuters) 
He said: “I think it is ideal that he has started out at the academy, working with young kids, because his career is proof that anything is possible. 
“He went from being a local boy in the academy to become one of the greatest players in the club’s history, so that is a fantastic example for those kids. 
“It is good that he has not just gone straight in as a manager somewhere else, when there is always the possibility of failing. It is better that he learns what it is all about at academy level first.” Gerrard following the action in a Liverpool U18s game earlier this month (Photo: PA) 
And in the week that marked the passing of Ronnie Moran , who went from Liverpool captain to coach some of the club’s greatest sides, Garcia said Gerrard will be following a great tradition. 
Bob Paisley and Kenny Dalglish both progressed from playing for the club to managing the Reds, and Garcia believes Gerrard can do the same.
